bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to Richard Maurice Bucke, 24 October 1891
bibl.idno: Letter: MSS18630, Box 7, Reel 4–5; Envelope: MSS18630, Box 7, Reel 4–5
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Young's stationery was a single folded sheet that created four surfaces. He wrote his letter to Whitman on surface one (which had a printed letterhead), left the verso (surface 2) blank, completed his letter on surface three, and left the verso (surface 4) blank. Whitman then wrote his own letter to Bucke on the blank surface 4.

revisionDesc.change: final check, corrected, added multitext encoding

body.p: Feeling fairly (no mark'd bad pressure)—This is f'm John Russell Young—declined with thanks—sent word to Frank Carpenter I w'd sit—Jeannette Gilder N Y. & three charming girls just here—I consider J G, & Jo: & the Critic, old & real & valuable friends—(have never halted or wavered)—the English "nibbling" pub'rs are Heinemann & Balestier (& it w'd seem J G Lovell N Y) & I have written to Forman, asking him to prospect & negotiate with them—have given him absolute power—J W W[allace] is here—to go down with the Staffords to-morrow—shall presently make my supper of oysters & a bit of pumpkin pie—
